docs.title: REROUTE
docs.text:
Modern file-based routing for Python backends

REROUTE brings the simplicity and elegance of Next.js-style file-based routing to Python web frameworks. Build clean, maintainable APIs with zero configuration.

docs.title: Why REROUTE?
docs.text:
• File-based Routing

    Organize routes by folders and files, just like Next.js.

    No more manual route registration!

  • Class-based Handlers

    HTTP methods as class methods: get(), post(), put(), delete()

    Clean, intuitive, and Pythonic

  • Powerful Decorators

    Built-in rate limiting, caching, validation, and more

    Extend with custom decorators easily

  • Multi-framework Support

    Works with FastAPI, Flask, Django, and more

    Switch frameworks without rewriting routes

docs.title: Quick Example
docs.text: Create a file-based route in 3 steps:

docs.title: 1. Install REROUTE
docs.text: pip install reroute

docs.title: 2. Create a route file
3. Register with your framework
docs.text:
FastAPIFlask main.py
from fastapi import FastAPI
from reroute.adapters import FastAPIAdapter
from pathlib import Path

app = FastAPI()
adapter = FastAPIAdapter(
    fastapi_app=app,
    app_dir=Path(__file__).parent / "app"
)
adapter.register_routes()
app.py
from flask import Flask
from reroute.adapters import FlaskAdapter
from pathlib import Path

app = Flask(__name__)
adapter = FlaskAdapter(
    flask_app=app,
    app_dir=Path(__file__).parent / "app"
)
adapter.register_routes()

That's it! Your routes are now available at /api/v1/user with automatic OpenAPI documentation.

docs.title: File-based Routing
docs.text:
Organize your API by filesystem structure. Each folder becomes a route segment:

app/routes/
├── user/
│   └── page.py        → /user
└── product/
    ├── page.py        → /product
    └── [id]/
        └── page.py    → /product/:id

docs.title: Decorators
docs.text:
Built-in decorators for common API patterns:

  • @rate_limit("5/min") - Rate limiting per IP/user
  • @cache(duration=60) - Response caching
  • @requires("admin") - Role-based access
  • @validate(schema) - Request validation
  • @timeout(5) - Request timeout
  • @log_requests() - Automatic logging

docs.title: Lifecycle Hooks
docs.text:
Control request/response flow with lifecycle methods:

class MyRoute(RouteBase):
    def before_request(self):
        # Authentication, validation
        pass

    def after_request(self, response):
        # Add headers, transform response
        return response

    def on_error(self, error):
        # Custom error handling
        return {"error": str(error)}

docs.title: Custom Configuration
docs.text:
Fine-tune REROUTE's behavior:

from reroute import Config

class MyConfig(Config):
    PORT = 8000
    API_BASE_PATH = "/api/v1"
    ENABLE_CORS = True
    CORS_ALLOW_ORIGINS = ["https://example.com"]
    VERBOSE_LOGGING = True

docs.title: Adapters
docs.text: REROUTE adapters integrate file-based routing with different Python web frameworks.

docs.title: Available Adapters
docs.text:
• FastAPI

    High-performance async framework with automatic API docs

  • Flask

    Lightweight and flexible WSGI framework

  • Django

    Full-featured framework (coming soon)

docs.title: How Adapters Work
docs.text:
Adapters translate REROUTE's file-based routes into framework-specific routes:

from reroute.adapters import FastAPIAdapter

adapter = FastAPIAdapter(
    fastapi_app=app,
    app_dir=Path(__file__).parent / "app"
)
adapter.register_routes()

docs.title: Common Features
docs.text:
All adapters support:

  • File-based routing discovery
  • HTTP method mapping (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, etc.)
  • Lifecycle hooks (before_request, after_request, on_error)
  • Decorator integration
  • Custom configuration

docs.title: RouteBase
docs.text:
from reroute import RouteBase

class MyRoute(RouteBase):
    tag = "Custom Tag"  # Optional Swagger tag

    def get(self):
        """Handle GET requests"""
        pass

    def before_request(self):
        """Run before every request"""
        return None

    def after_request(self, response):
        """Run after successful request"""
        return response

    def on_error(self, error):
        """Handle errors"""
        return {"error": str(error)}

docs.title: Simple API
docs.text:
from reroute import RouteBase

class UserRoutes(RouteBase):
    def __init__(self):
        super().__init__()
        self.users = []

    def get(self):
        return {"users": self.users}

    def post(self):
        user = {"id": len(self.users) + 1}
        self.users.append(user)
        return user

docs.title: With Decorators
docs.text:
from reroute import RouteBase, rate_limit, cache

class ProductRoutes(RouteBase):
    @cache(duration=300)
    def get(self):
        # Cached for 5 minutes
        return {"products": [...]}

    @rate_limit("10/min")
    def post(self):
        # Max 10 requests per minute
        return {"created": True}

docs.title: With Lifecycle Hooks
docs.text:
from reroute import RouteBase

class SecureRoutes(RouteBase):
    def before_request(self):
        # Check authentication
        if not self.is_authenticated():
            raise Unauthorized("Login required")
        return None

    def after_request(self, response):
        # Add security headers
        response["X-API-Version"] = "1.0"
        return response

    def on_error(self, error):
        # Custom error handling
        return {"error": str(error), "status": 500}

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text: Welcome to REROUTE! This guide will help you get started with file-based routing for Python backends.

docs.title: What is REROUTE?
docs.text: REROUTE is a modern routing framework that brings Next.js-style file-based routing to Python web frameworks. Instead of manually registering routes, you organize them in folders and files - REROUTE handles the rest.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Python 3.8 or higher
  • A web framework (FastAPI, Flask, or Django)
  • Basic understanding of REST APIs

docs.title: From PyPI (Recommended)
docs.text: pip install reroute

docs.title: With specific framework support
docs.text:
FastAPIFlaskAll frameworks 
pip install reroute[fastapi]

pip install reroute[flask]

pip install reroute[all]

docs.title: From Source
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/cbsajan/reroute.git
cd reroute
pip install -e .

docs.title: Your First Route
docs.text: Let's create your first file-based route with REROUTE.

docs.title: Understanding File-based Routing
docs.text:
In REROUTE, the folder structure determines your API routes:

app/routes/
└── user/
    └── page.py  → /user endpoint

The page.py file contains the route logic as a class.

docs.title: 1. Create the File Structure
docs.text: mkdir -p app/routes/hello

docs.title: 2. Create the Route Handler
docs.text:
Create app/routes/hello/page.py:

from reroute import RouteBase

class HelloRoutes(RouteBase):
    """Simple hello world route"""

    def get(self):
        """Handle GET requests"""
        return {"message": "Hello, REROUTE!"}

docs.title: 3. Register with Your App
docs.text:
In your main.py:

from fastapi import FastAPI
from reroute.adapters import FastAPIAdapter
from pathlib import Path

app = FastAPI()
adapter = FastAPIAdapter(
    fastapi_app=app,
    app_dir=Path(__file__).parent / "app"
)
adapter.register_routes()

docs.title: 4. Test It
docs.text:
curl http://localhost:8000/hello
# {"message": "Hello, REROUTE!"}

docs.title: Adding Multiple HTTP Methods
docs.text:
Handle different HTTP methods with corresponding class methods:

from reroute import RouteBase

class TodoRoutes(RouteBase):
    """Todo management routes"""

    tag = "Todos"

    def __init__(self):
        super().__init__()
        self.todos = []

    def get(self):
        """Get all todos"""
        return {"todos": self.todos}

    def post(self):
        """Create a todo"""
        todo = {"id": len(self.todos) + 1, "title": "New Todo"}
        self.todos.append(todo)
        return {"created": todo}

    def put(self):
        """Update a todo"""
        return {"message": "Todo updated"}

    def delete(self):
        """Delete a todo"""
        if self.todos:
            deleted = self.todos.pop()
            return {"deleted": deleted}
        return {"message": "No todos to delete"}

docs.title: Adding Custom Swagger Tags
docs.text:
Organize your API documentation with custom tags:

class UserRoutes(RouteBase):
    tag = "User Management"  # Shows in Swagger UI

    def get(self):
        return {"users": []}

docs.title: Using State
docs.text:
Store state in your route class:

class CounterRoutes(RouteBase):
    """Simple counter API"""

    def __init__(self):
        super().__init__()
        self.count = 0

    def get(self):
        """Get current count"""
        return {"count": self.count}

    def post(self):
        """Increment count"""
        self.count += 1
        return {"count": self.count}

docs.title: Route Method Signatures
docs.text:
Each HTTP method can accept different parameters based on your framework:

FastAPIFlask 
from fastapi import Request, Response

class MyRoutes(RouteBase):
    def get(self, request: Request):
        return {"ip": request.client.host}

    def post(self, request: Request):
        body = await request.json()
        return {"received": body}

from flask import request

class MyRoutes(RouteBase):
    def get(self):
        return {"ip": request.remote_addr}

    def post(self):
        body = request.get_json()
        return {"received": body}

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text: Build your first REROUTE application in 5 minutes!

docs.title: Step 1: Install REROUTE
docs.text: pip install reroute[fastapi]

docs.title: Step 2: Create Project Structure
docs.text:
mkdir my-reroute-app
cd my-reroute-app
mkdir -p app/routes/user

Your structure should look like:

my-reroute-app/
├── app/
│   └── routes/
│       └── user/
│           └── page.py
└── main.py

docs.title: Step 3: Create a Route
docs.text:
Create app/routes/user/page.py:

from reroute import RouteBase

class UserRoutes(RouteBase):
    """User management routes"""

    tag = "Users"

    def get(self):
        """Get all users"""
        return {
            "users": [
                {"id": 1, "name": "Alice"},
                {"id": 2, "name": "Bob"}
            ]
        }

    def post(self):
        """Create a user"""
        return {"message": "User created", "id": 3}

docs.title: Step 4: Create Main Application
docs.text:
Create main.py:

from fastapi import FastAPI
from reroute.adapters import FastAPIAdapter
from pathlib import Path

app = FastAPI(title="My REROUTE App")

adapter = FastAPIAdapter(
    fastapi_app=app,
    app_dir=Path(__file__).parent / "app"
)
adapter.register_routes()

if __name__ == "__main__":
    import uvicorn
    uvicorn.run(app, host="0.0.0.0", port=8000)

docs.title: Step 5: Run the Application
docs.text:
python main.py

Visit:

  • API Docs: http://localhost:8000/docs
  • Users endpoint: http://localhost:8000/user

docs.title: Step 6: Test Your API
docs.text:

curl http://localhost:8000/user

# Create user
curl -X POST http://localhost:8000/user
